column4: Hey all, I'm trying to boot a debootstrapped ubuntu 11.04 system, but the console login isn't appearing. Init seems to just hang after parsing rc.local.
You got agetty, bash etc?
You don't understand what initcpio/initrd does, do you
initrd is loaded in order to load the proper kernel modules, i.e. device drivers, after which it's gone from the RAM pretty much
Well, some distros keep it forever (becuase they intend to run from RAM)
Not the case with Ubuntu
Half-window manager, it has things desktop environments tend to have (panels, trays, etc etc)
No root password
gksudo synaptic
Ubuntu doesn't officially support setting the root password. If you do that, you're no longer eglible to receive support from this channel, Ubuntu forums, etc.
And yeah, use sudo/gksudo. They make much more sense than plain su alternatives of theirs.
Use gksudo. Or open "gksu-properties" and tell it to use sudo through that. That way, both gksu and gksudo will act the same
hmm yeah, I tried using gksu-properties, but the settings aren't saved on a dbusless chroot of 11.04. :/
Ouch... Using desktop environments without dbus is generally a bad idea
it's not a full blown DE, just that stuff like gksu which AptUrl uses is by default in, ah, 'su' mode. *cough*
That's weird, since if I recall right, gksu by *default* actually uses the sudo mode in Ubuntu, but then again it might act strangely because of lack of dbus
would it be possible for me to temporarily set up dbus inside the chroot from the host system?
Probably, I'm not into chroots, sorry about that. But basically "apt-get install dbus" in it, start the dbus daemon and that should be about it
I think gksu as well as gksudo relies heavily on dbus to perform the authorisation, so if you don't have that it will fail... It's just a wild guess, but something makes me think that's the case.
well, I was trying this out from the chroot-as-livecd, which starts up dbus and such.
Ah, then sorry, no idea.
Have you tried runing gksu with --sudo-mode and/or --debug? Might help...
sudo -u username -i
Or, "su username". Well. That works fine for non-root
